utterances: It can do media that you just don't have any other strategies.
I can cut stone.
It can cut glass.
Autodesk makes software for 3-D printers, manufacturing plants, construction sites, architects.
Noah Weinstein, senior creative program manager, came up with the idea to open up the workshops to artists.
And this is a new vocabulary of software and a new vocabulary of using these tools for creative output.
And I think the artist is a great explorer to ask those question about what should these tools be doing, what do they do best and what's not working.
So twice a year, Autodesk admits 16 artists to its four-month residency program.
The each get full access to the workshops and a stipend.
Often, the people who apply have backgrounds in both technology and the arts.
Take Scott Killdall, a sculptor who has an MFA in art and technology studies.

So there's been these two parts of my brain, and I've been wanting to combine code with sculpture for so many years and wanting to do digital fabrication of taking the code and generating the objects.
Which he's done here at Autodesk.
Kildall got all kinds of data about San Francisco's water systems.
Among his discoveries, there are cisterns below the streets that were installed shortly after San Francisco's devastating 1906 earthquake.
Killdall used the 3-D printers to create a sculpture of this underground system.
It's small enough to wrap your arms around it.
The cisterns looks like ivory-colored votive candles connected by a system of translucent pipes, and it's all in the shape of San Francisco's famous hills.
This looks a little like ""Battlestar Galactica."" It looks like the ship a little bit, you see (laughter)?
Yeah.
I would say they look kind of organic-alien.
So there's an organic structure to them because they follow the topography of San Francisco so they have these natural curves and boundaries.
And just as Autodesk hoped, Killdall's project challenged the software by overloading it with data.
Each of these models took about 40 to 50 hours to print.
The nice part of this residency is that he could work with the engineers to overcome the challenges.
They learned and so did he.
Laura Devendorf, another artist in residence, was also challenged by the 3-D printers.
My adviser and I were trying to think of a way to do 3-D printing with everyday materials.
So how could you just be in the world, in public, maybe grabbing sticks or leaves and actually making these 3-D objects out of them?
3-D printers work by using an extruder that layers up melted material until it creates a solid object.
Devendorf realized it wasn't going to work with sticks.
There was something missing from the process - humans.
She configured the printer to use a laser light to show humans how to do the layering.
So I'm actually asking people to perform manually the functions that 3-D printers do.
Seriously?
Yes.
(LAUGHTER)
An odd exercise, perhaps, but one which Devendorf says is meant to raise questions about the role of machine versus human labor.
Autodesk is not the only artist in residence program in the tech world.
Facebook has a program, and there's a history of such collaboration in tech companies.
Xerox PARC, famously known as the place that helped develop the computer mouse and the graphical user interface, had an artist in residence program.
John Seely Brown ran PARC for 20 years.
He says in a time where technology is providing us with infinite possibilities...
...Where the ability to imagine is the key challenge because we have infinitely powerful tools to build whatever we imagine.
As a result, we're limited by our imagination.
Working with artists really opens our imagination.
Brown believes that if we want technology that solves big problems in elegant, human-centered ways, we need artists to be part of the process.
Laura Sydell, NPR News, San Francisco.
Last month, Utah Governor Gary Herbert signed a bill bringing back the firing squad as a method of execution.
The state abandoned firing squads in 2004.
Now, it's returned as the backup option.
Governor Herbert says lethal injection is still the default if the drugs are available.
(SOUNDBITE OF ARCHIVED RECORDING)
Alexander and Brown based their research on the work of University of Delaware professor Danilo Yanich, who created a database of thousands of local TV news stories from 20 U.S.
media markets.
The FCC's rulings on media ownership will affect such big national companies as Tribune, which hopes to hold onto major newspapers and television stations in the same markets.
That is largely barred under current rules.
Other major companies, such as News Corp.
and Sinclair Broadcast Group, have stretched FCC regulations as they've expanded their television holdings.
They each own several dozen stations across the country.
But back in the summer of 2004, Candeub and Yanich say, FCC bosses stopped the local news study cold.
Staffers were told to destroy or return any copies they had of it.
So the report was never released until this week, following Senate hearings on President Bush's renomination of FCC Chairman Kevin Martin.
Sen.
Barbara Boxer, a California Democrat, surprised Martin after he promised to consider media consolidation carefully.
Well, let me tell you why I have a problem with your answer.
I mean, I'm very happy with what you're going to do, but I think there's work that's been done and it's been stifled.
And I don't know who stifled it.
Boxer said someone had sent her the report anonymously.
I think this is news, that this kind of work has never seen the light of day.
Do you have any clue who may have stopped the release here of this report?
As I said, it's dated in June of '04.
I became chairman in March of '05.
Were you a commissioner then?
I was a commissioner.
Okay.
Martin told Boxer he knew nothing about it.
His predecessor, Michael Powell, also denied any knowledge of the report in an interview with NPR.
Never saw it.
Never reviewed it.
Never ordered it be stifled in any way.
So any suggestion that senior level of the commission spiked that report, at least from my vantage point, didn't happen.
Powell says tough limits were needed for radio, but it was time to ease the regulations limiting how many local TV stations a company could own.

I think that any honest evaluation of the media landscape necessarily - and I think as a matter of intellectual honesty - must include the plethora of exploding new technologies and the kinds of changes they're bringing to the media environment.
Powell says he would have happily considered the FCC study on local news coverage along with others that he says show corporate owners do a better job.
Former FCC lawyer Adam Candeub says Powell and Martin had already made up their minds.
It seems like the agency can be so craven that they want to sort of generate this alternate reality that's consistent with what the commissioners want to see.
Senator Boxer is now calling for an inspector general to investigate the episode.
David Folkenflik, NPR News, Washington.
To read a draft of the report and hear more of Senator Boxer, Chairman Martin and former Chairman Powell, visit NPR.org.
Eleanor Beardsley reports from Paris.
French daily newspaper FranÃÂ§ois published all 12 of the controversial Danish cartoons in its Wednesday edition under the headline, Yes We Do Have the Right to Caricature God.
Newspapers in Italy, Spain, Germany, Switzerland, and Holland also printed some of the Danish cartoons.
FranÃÂ§ois' Deputy Editor Avro Lavi(ph) said his paper decided to publish not to provoke, but to cover a news story.
The wave of indignation all across the Muslim world.
And this wave of indignation had reached to a scale of diplomatic crisis so we wondered what was the cause of such anger.
Mohammed Ahman Habom (ph), the head of the Central Council of Muslims in Germany says it won't be easy to calm tensions now.
Any Muslim who sees these images will feel deeply hurt and will definitely come to the conclusion that this was done on purpose, not to defend the freedom of the press, but to spite the Muslims.
The affair is pulling in top European officials who are working feverishly to try to calm the situation.
French Foreign Minister Philippe Douste-Blazy (ph), whose country has Europe's largest Muslim population, appealed for tolerance while traveling in Turkey today.
And the Danish Ambassador to Paris, Neils Eglund (ph), had a meeting with the head of the French Muslim Community.
The purpose of the visit was to try to stop the excesses that this has taken.
It was an appeal to good sense, an appeal to dialog and understanding between cultures and religions.
